Calculating an Angle from [imath]2[/imath] points in space

Given two points [imath]$p_1$[/imath] , [imath]$p_2$[/imath] around the origin [imath](0,0)[/imath] in [imath]2D[/imath] space, how would you calculate the angle from [imath]p_1[/imath] to [imath]p_2[/imath]? How would this change in [imath]3D[/imath] space? 

__ANSWER__

Assuming this is relative to the origin (as John pointed out): Given two position vectors [imath]\vec p_1[/imath] and [imath]\vec p_2[/imath], their dot product is: [imath]\vec p_1\cdot \vec p_2 = |\vec p_1| \cdot |\vec p_2| \cdot \cos \theta[/imath] Solving for [imath]\theta[/imath], we get: [imath]\theta = \arccos\left(\frac{\vec p_1 \cdot \vec p_2}{|\vec p_1| \cdot |\vec p_2|}\right)[/imath] In a 2D space this equals: [imath]v = \arccos\left(\frac{x_1x_2 + y_1y_2}{\sqrt{(x_1^2+y_1^2) \cdot (x_2^2+y_2^2)}}\right)[/imath] And extended for 3D space: [imath]v = \arccos\left(\frac{x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 + z_1z_2}{\sqrt{(x_1^2+y_1^2+z_1^2) \cdot (x_2^2+y_2^2+z_2^2)}}\right)[/imath]
